metadata.description: What you should beware of when you collect the data.

all_paragraphs: In statistics, you can make a mistake literally at every step. You might ask a question irrelevant to your problem, wrongly define the population of interest, make a bug in your analysis, etc.

One of the most vulnerable moments is the data collection. It’s because what you get at this step is what you base your final decision on. Today, let’s discuss a few common pitfalls that can make great disfavour of your perfect data collection process.

First let us introduce our main enemy — bias. In statistics by bias we mean a systematic distortion of the data (on contrary to variance, which is chaotic). You can imagine an archer shooting a target and hitting just below the center all the time. In the same way e.g. your data on college students’ height might be notoriously overestimating the measurements because of the faulty equipment.
The problem is that you don’t always know if and how your data is skewed. That’s why it is important to be aware of the dangers just waiting to break your analysis.

Many companies were forced to close the offices because of the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. Wherever possible, the workers do their job from home. Some IT companies, like Twitter or Facebook, have even decided to allow their employees to work from home indefinitely. Many people wonder whether it is a good decision. After all, aren’t people less productive then? Imagine you are a director in a tech company and consider such move. You might want to find out how the people working in the industry feel about it and whether they have any problems working this way.
Imagine you prepared a form with questions you are interested in and sent it out to the people. Let’s discuss some scenarios.
Scenario I: You sent out an email with the questions to all your employees.

This is pretty convenient — you have all the addresses and maybe you even trust that your employees won’t lie (more about that problem below). But in the first place you wanted to learn something about all the people in the IT industry, not only from your company. Your colleagues probably won’t be a representative sample of the population. Maybe you have a cool office that everyone wants to get back to? Or your employees are highly motivated people who have no concentration problems at home? You don’t know that.
The way you collect the data excludes a part of the population from the sample. Hence it is not representative — this kind of bias is called undercoverage bias.
Scenario II: In order to reach more people you posted the form on your company’s public blog.

Now everyone is covered — every person with an internet access can reach your form (and you assume that all IT workers have internet) so you don’t leave anyone out. But is everyone equally probable to answer your questions? Since the article is posted on your company’s blog, your employees will be more likely to read it and hence fill your form (even if they won’t be the only ones to do it).
Your sampling method prefers some people over others, resulting in a selection bias.
Scenario III: You have hired a company specialising in polls to find a representative sample of IT industry workers and provide you with their email addresses.

Seems perfect, right? You managed to contact a representative sample of a population you are interested in. There is still one problem — not everyone will reply. And the people that don’t answer your question won’t be just some random folks, they might have some common reason not to reply.
That’s why you might end up with a nonresponse bias. It’s not enough to reach out to a representative sample — your answers are the data you are interested in at the end of the day.
Scenario IV: Tired with failures you’ve hired a hacker to block computers of a representative sample of IT industry workers until they fill out your form.

This time it has to work, right? No way anyone will throw away their computer just to avoid filling some short form. But the fact that you got the answers does not mean that they are honest. After all, people are angry now and they might lie. They also know that you will somehow use them so they might trick you to believe something that suits them. Perhaps they are afraid that the data won’t be properly anonymised and they don’t want to admit to their unproductivity? Or maybe they want you to think that WFH is great and they will say that they love it just because they want to have this option?
This is probably one of the most difficult situations to defend from — you get the answers but you don’t know if they are true — we call it a response bias.

Be aware that there are more kinds of biases that might sneak into your data and you should always consider what might be wrong. They include, but are not limited to observer bias, attrition bias, recall bias, etc. Wikipedia describes some of them. There is a great xkcd cartoon on survivorship bias too.

Your data might look perfectly fine but it might lead you to wrong conclusions, even if it is just slightly off from the reality. It is hard to defend yourself from biases, but being aware of what might go wrong will help you avoid many mistakes.
If you’re interested to see some real life mistakes being made, we recommend having a look at a recent article by Cassie Kozykov about study on COVID-19 infections in New York City.
This article has been written together with Tomasz Wesołowski. Check out his new article, where he describes the difference between inference and prediction.
